fields.descriptive_line: Design on paper, perhaps for a plate, by Charles Rennie Mackintosh, Glasgow, 1900-1910.
fields.physical_description: A design plan based on concentric circles, for the decoration of a plate. In the centre is a shamrock-like motif with squares radiating outwards. Pencil marks and light grey wash suggests the three-dimensional form of the plate. The colouring and pattern is incomplete. The sheet has been divided into eighths by pencil lines .
fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level F, case EDUC, shelf 10
Prints & Drawings Study Room, level F

fields.name: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level F

fields.public_access_description:
The plate design is similar to those displayed on the shelves on the left-hand side of the 'Art Lover's Dining Room', designed by Mackintosh in 1901, and was probably for a decorative, rather than a practical purpose. The decoration is unfinished and the technique that Mackintosh uses to build up the design can be clearly seen: the circular plan is in pencil with a light wash used for shading and defining the three-dimensional form of the plate and a radial line, hatching marks to indicate the "dip" in the centre of the plate and finally watercolour for the decoration. The pattern radiates from and echoes the wavy form of the shamrock in the centre point which is contained in a quatrefoil. Around the rim, however, is a frieze of the small neat squares typical of Mackintosh's work. 
The plate design is similar to those displayed on the shelves on the left-hand side of the 'Art Lover's Dining Room' and was probably for a decorative, rather than a practical purpose. It is unfinished and the technique that Mackintosh uses to build up the design can be seen: the circular plan is in pencil with a light wash used for shading and a radial line, hatching marks to indicate the "dip" in the centre of the plate and finally watercolour for the decoration. The pattern radiates from and echoes the wavy form of the clover in the centre point which is contained in a quatrefoil. Around the rim, however, is a frieze of the small neat squares typical of Mackintosh's work. 

The plate design is similar to those displayed on the shelves on the left-hand side of the 'Art Lover's Dining Room' and was probably for a decorative, rather than a practical purpose. It is unfinished and the technique that Mackintosh uses to build up the design can be seen: the circular plan is in pencil with a light wash used for shading and a radial line, hatching marks to indicate the "dip" in the centre of the plate and finally watercolour for the decoration. The pattern radiates from and echoes the wavy form of the clover in the centre point which is contained in a quatrefoil. Around the rim, however, is a frieze of the small neat squares typical of Mackintosh's work. 
It is in the bold style which is typical of Mackintosh's later work.
fields.bibliography: Fiona Leslie, Design for 20th-Century Interiors, 2000, p.73. Victoria and Albert Museum Department of Prints and Drawings and Department of Paintings Accessions 1968 London: HMSO, 1969 The full text of the entry is as follows: "MACKINTOSH, Charles Rennie (1868-1928) The following designs, E.839-867-1968, were formerly in the collection of the late William Meldrum, Secretary of the Mackintosh Memorial Exhibition, Glasgow, 1933, father of the donor. … Designs (4), based on concentric circles. Possibly for ceramic decoration. Pencil and water-colour. E.860-863-1968 Given by Mr. James Meldrum"
